text: So hi, my name is Catherine Deatley and I teach kindergarten at Meriwether Lewis. And like many of the teachers in the county, I want nothing more than to go back to the classroom and be with my students. But I only want that when it is safe for everyone. When I read an AEA email stating the county was planning on proposing we go to phase three in November, my anxiety levels immediately went through the roof.  The three main reasons for this anxiety are health, choice, and student impact. As an asthmatic, the idea of going back in a person during a global pandemic that involves a respiratory illness scares me. And as much as I want to see my students and my colleagues, the fear of possibly coming into contact with someone who unknowingly has COVID is real for any teacher, staff member, and student that is considered high risk. This leads me to my second reason for the anxiety, the choice I may have to make.  If the rumor mill is true, then teachers will be given a choice to either go face-to-face or stay virtual. If we go face-to-face, we get to keep our class. If we remain virtual, then we lose our class. We lose our students that we have spent weeks getting to know and have built relationships, bonds, and trust with.  I love and adore my students. And while virtual learning is not the ideal situation, we are making it work the best that we can. My students continue to amaze me every day with their resilience, persistence, kindness, and patience. And yes, there have been a few bumps here and there, but we are able to push on because we know that we are in this together. We continue to learn through singing, movement, discussion, art, games, play, and exploration. My kids are even  writing at this point. All approaches that we are using are developmentally appropriate. And lastly, I have extreme anxiety over the learning experience my students will have if we go back face to face too soon. Research will tell you that our youngest learners learn best through play, movement, music, interaction, and hands-on exploration.  If we go back face-to-face where we have to follow strict safety measures, the majority of what we know to be developmentally appropriate will be unusable. Instead, it will be replaced with our students trying to sit in a desk for the majority of their school day, six feet from the friends that they just wanna play with, looking at the toys that they can't play with. There will be no group exploration of dirt or games of chase on the playground. If we aren't able to teach our students in the best way we know how, just so they can stay safe,  then what kind of education are we truly providing them with? And to ACPS, what is more important, keeping everyone safe while providing a developmentally appropriate education or simply putting warm bodies in a building where they will receive a mediocre education and run the risk of getting sick? Please fight for us and do what is right for everybody. Thank you for your time. And Katrina, thank you for saying my last name correctly.

text: All right, well, in that case, I am going to go ahead and start my time. My name is Maggie Johnson. I am the German one and two teacher at Monticello High School here in Albemarle County. I live in Charlottesville City, but I teach in the county and I'm proud to. I'd like to first make it clear that my comments represent exclusively my own perspective and my own concerns. I do not claim to speak for any other teachers or any other staff or faculty in the county.  I think it goes without saying that this virtual school year is not our ideal. I miss seeing my students. I am only in my second year of teaching, but I already have grown to love being in a physical classroom and being around students, and I miss them. And I miss the spontaneity of in-person teaching, and I miss being able to create a physical space to let my students learn and grow as people and within the boundaries of the language that I teach.  But even considering the shortcomings of virtual education, the fact of the matter is that it is not safe for in-person instruction, even on a hybrid level, and it will not be safe to return to in-person instruction until there is an effective and accessible vaccine available. Put plainly, if we return to in-person schooling, even on a hybrid schedule, people will become sick with COVID-19,  and people will die of COVID-19 as a direct result of that decision. Instead of worrying about when and how to return to in-person instruction, I think that the school board and the county as a whole need to focus on how to facilitate the best possible online instruction.  The questions of when and how to return to in-person classes should not even be considered until the CDC approves distribution of a vaccine, and that vaccine is made accessible to every person. Instead, I would like for the school board to focus their efforts solely on supporting teachers, staff, students, and families in the district with online education.  I genuinely believe that if we accept that this is our reality for the foreseeable future, instead of deluding ourselves with thinking we can return to in-person or hybrid for the 2020-21 year, we can learn powerful lessons as a county and as individuals to take into our instruction when it is safe. To emphasize that point to the minute I have left, I'd like to offer some improvements that I've already begun to see in my planning and teaching, even in these first three weeks of classes.  Being limited to 45 minutes of direct synchronous instruction at the high school level means that I am making more deliberate intentional decisions about what, when, and how to teach material. This is allowing me to explore a flipped approach to my classes in which students take notes on grammatical structures or learn vocabulary asynchronously. And we then practice during synchronous classes. I am also able to focus more closely on students achieving proficiency and understanding with the material instead of feeling pressured to assign record graded exercises or assignments.  The online format further means that I can explore new programs and technologies to incorporate into class, such as Flipgrid or Edpuzzle, which I've already started to use Flipgrid in my classes to make learning more engaging and more accessible to every student. When the day comes that it's safe to return to in-person, I'll be able to use these technologies as part of my standard curriculum because I'll have had plenty of experience using them in a variety of ways. That's all of the time that I have, but I have submitted comments via email to the school board that I would like for you to please review  when you're considering the next steps for the county. Thank you.
speaker: maggiejohnson

text: Thank you, Miss Johnson. Next up will be Mr. Andrew West.

text: Thank you. Thank you very much, Mr. Page. So I just have a great announcement to make. It's really exciting.  Earlier today, the U.S. Department of Education announced their National Blue Ribbon Awards for Excellence in Academic Performance. For the first time in the program's 38-year history, a Virginia school has received the department's Exemplary Award for Closing Achievement Gaps. I'm proud to say that our own Baker Butler is one of four schools in our state to meet the very high standards for this recognition.  In fact, of the 1,800 schools in Virginia, only 58 even qualified in this category. The award covers three school years beginning with 2016-17. Over this time period, SOL pass rates for English language learners, special education students, and students from economically disadvantaged homes increased by 87% for math and 78% in reading.  Yes, those are increases, not the pass rate. This far exceeded the increase in overall pass rates of 15% in math and 11% in reading in Virginia. As a result, the achievement gap in reading was reduced from 24 down to 11 percentage points, and the gap in math fell from 16 percentage points to six.  These achievements will be featured in our spotlight on education during our October the 8th meeting, but I would like to congratulate the outstanding and remarkably talented faculty, staff, students, families, and of course, previous principal Steve Saunders and current principal Seth Kennard for your outstanding work. This is a nationally renowned accomplishment.  And as impressive as these numbers are, I know the school's motto will be the best is yet to come. Thank you.

Both Ryan and Eileen are incredibly well-versed in how COVID-19 is impacting our region, and they look forward to sharing their expertise with you tonight. As you recall, our return to school plan outlined multiple factors that we'll use to determine  when we move forward with our next stage. All data that you see tonight has been provided by the Virginia Department of Health. And it's important to note that these statistics and trend data are one factor in determining the move forward or back in our return to school stages. It's recommended that the board continue to look at all factors collectively as these decisions are made. And at this time, I'll turn things over to Eileen and Ryan to take you through the latest statistics and answer any questions that you may have.

text: Good evening. Thank you, Dr. McLaughlin. I'm Eileen Gomez. I am the school nurse coordinator and the COVID coordinator this year for Albemarle County Public Schools. And I would like to take you through the latest updates on the metrics that we have gotten from the Virginia Department of Health. As you can see, this first slide is the seven day floating average of the number of cases per 100,000 people.  and see that the numbers have, well, they call this trend fluctuating, but the numbers are lower now than they were in the end of August. And overall, we've been seeing a downward trend with the case burden or the floating average of the cases.  The percent positivity rate for testing in Elmar County has been steadily going down. You can see we're down at 3.6%, which is one of the lowest rates we've had at least all summer. That has been decreasing. Now in the city of Charlottesville, it's a little bit different. We have been on an upward trend of number of cases.  Some of that can be, I think most of the increase can be attributed to UVA cases. But we wanted to explain that the metrics we received from the Virginia Department of Health are intended to provide a starting point for conversations and decision making. We do not have absolute benchmarks for which people are clamoring.  It is, we believe it's important to contextualize the data. For example, UVA does have an impact on the case counts in the city, but not so much on the county. Luckily, we have Ryan McKay with us this evening, and he can help explain some of this data and put it into some context and may be able to answer any questions you have.
speaker: eileengomez

text: Ryan?  Thank you, Eileen, appreciate that. So, again, my name is Ryan McKay, senior policy analyst for the Thomas Jefferson Health District. And one of the things that we've been looking at closely throughout the pandemic are a lot of the numbers as they relate to positivity rates, the raw data of case counts, and certainly the cases per 100,000, both on a daily basis, but over the course of a 14 day period of time. And I think Eileen hits the point very well in terms of context.  what goes into these numbers, what goes into the seven-day positivity trend of 3.6. There are a number of factors that we have to consider when it comes to decision-making, whether it's for schools bringing students back or implementing community-wide mitigation strategies that the Board of Supervisors implemented back in late July and early August.  So part of that is understanding where we've been doing testing and where the positive results come from. If we do a point prevalence survey in let's say a long term care facility or at the regional jail.  One of the things that we would look for are the total number of positives related to those. Those will drive up many of the numbers in our localities. For example, Fluvanna County was at about 3.2 to 3.4% just over a week ago, and now they're up over 7.4% positivity rate over the last seven days. We can attribute that to one event in the outbreak at the Fluvanna Correctional Facility for Women.  Similarly, we can identify increases based on relationships with the university and student transmission there. While we haven't really seen the huge uptick within the county, we can attribute some of the cases and the case incidence rate 100,000 to students who live in the county or cases that are attributable to UVA in general.  And so I think it's really important to understand what the background is to some of these testing rates. The other is, and I think it might be a little confusing, sometimes is with the UVA, I'm sorry, the Charlottesville numbers, you notice that they're in bright red. It's at 48 per 100,000, but the positivity rate is below 5%, which is ideal for what we need to do as public health.  What that tells us is there's massive amounts of testing going on, and that's not just limited to UVA testing students and faculty. That goes to community testing that's happening throughout Albemarle County and Charlottesville and throughout the health district on a daily and weekly basis.  The more we test, the greater access that we provide to that testing, and the more frequently we do that, the idea is that we want to find those cases. We want to make sure that we can isolate individuals who test positive, that we can identify their close contacts, those who are within six feet for more than 15 minutes at a time, who may need to quarantine and monitor for symptoms themselves.  And that's really critical, because from our perspective, we want to make contact with those individuals within 24 hours. The more we can do that, the more likely it is that we can contain, not just mitigate. Difference being mitigation slows the spread, containing stops it. From our perspective, one of the important data points that isn't necessarily publicly released is our ability to do that within 24 hours. And we feel pretty confident that we can do that consistently at or above the 95% rate.  So I think the context behind the data is important. And as Eileen mentioned, it's a starting point for a broader discussion to determine what the risk may be. We heard often tonight about safe. And I think that's really hard to define. What we can better define is potential risk involved. And what are we doing, not just in relation to the positivity rates and the case counts,  But what are we doing holistically as a community to mitigate and minimize risk? It goes to wearing the face masks, physically distancing, doing symptom checks as a whole system as opposed to just focusing on what the percent positivities are.  We have examples within our health district and within the state of schools that have opened at varying levels of positivity rates, at varying levels of cases per 100,000. And I think what it's important is to, yes, look at those data points as a part of the conversation, but also understand what the ability is of a school system to implement the strategies that are going to reduce and minimize risk to the greatest extent possible.  So with that, I'm happy to answer questions about the data, about indicators, and any other questions you have about COVID-19 from the public health perspective.

text: Of course, yes. I believe there are ways that it can be done, and I've seen it. I visited Louisa County Public Schools about two weeks ago and got a tour of their middle and high school from their superintendent, Doug Straley, who showed me every step of the way of how they have worked to minimize and reduce risk to the extent possible, from the screening procedures that they have  how they do symptom checks and temperature checks, how they have students enter various parts of the building based on grade level, and how they've cohorted students. Now I will say a lot of what's occurred and what we're hearing is that this is pretty common across Virginia.  is that they're able to decompress the number of students who are doing in-person education. So they had about a one-third of parents decide to keep students home for full virtual education, so that left them with two-thirds of their school system attending school in person.  I believe they're on an AB schedule. And so while school doesn't look like school in terms of the numbers and what a classroom looks like, they have been very successful at bringing students back, implementing policies such as face masks, putting markers on the floor, stickers on the floor as reminders of how to do physical and social distancing. Six feet can be sort of  hard to navigate if you're standing in a line without that visual reference. So the strategies they put in at both levels have been pretty remarkable to see. And I'll be honest, I had a hard time getting my head around what a school looks like during COVID and how you can minimize risk to the extent possible. And they've done a tremendous job. And they've also had some strong protocols as it relates to  What happens if we've identified an individual with COVID who's a member of the school community? What do we do in terms of information sharing, contact tracing, and then education following that to ensure that we've identified as public health all the people that may have been a close contact and that we've done everything we can to contain potential spread?  And so they've been a very good example. I know Greene County opened a couple of weeks ago. My understanding is Dr. Hawes talked to Andrea Whitmarsh, their superintendent, and we've heard nothing but good things there. In fact, Greene County visited Louisa County just to get an idea of what was happening. And they've been very open about what didn't necessarily work to begin with and what they've adjusted on the fly to make those operations, again, with low risk or minimizing risk to the extent possible.  I will say it's important to keep in mind that as schools open, whether it's Albemarle County or Charlottesville or anywhere in Virginia,  We have to anticipate there may be a case that emerges, and we have to understand that our response to that is going to impact whether or not we contain spread, mitigate spread, or if spread moves forward. And so that planning process, that constant review of those plans, and learning from others, along with looking at the community data, is going to be an ongoing process. It's evolving.  But again, to reiterate to your original question, yes, I believe it can be done in a way that minimizes risk to the extent possible, as long as there's a sort of a systems approach to that in combination with what we can provide and share through data and context around that data.
